channel.title: PHP or HTML
channel.description: Which one do I learn first? Which is more powerful? (I think PHP but...) I want to get into website developing :P

item.title: PHP or HTML
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

Uncalled:

php sucks.

item.title: PHP or HTML
item.dc:creator: @xen0n xen0n
item.description:
@xen0n wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:18, topic:451238”][quote author=xen0n link=topic=554127.msg4061490#msg4061490 date=1343462670]
Begin with HTML/XHTML to learn the basic structure of a website.

Then move to CSS to get an understanding of how you can style your website.

In reality you can make a really nice website with just HTML and CSS but PHP is required for login or data sending for MySQL.

HTML > CSS > PHP > MySQL

That is the order I started learning.
[/quote]why are you putting sql after php? that’s more like together generally speaking.[/quote]

That is true, I’ve edited my post.

Read full topic

item.title: PHP or HTML
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Should definitely get a basic understanding of the html tags before learning PHP, but I believe it should be HTML > CSS > JS > PHP.
Then you can use the skills from php to learn other similar languages if needed, I’ve recently found c# and asp.net to be quite easy to learn because I had a fair amount of php (and sql) knowledge.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:

[quote=“xen0n, post:17, topic:451238”]Begin with HTML/XHTML to learn the basic structure of a website.

Then move to CSS to get an understanding of how you can style your website.

In reality you can make a really nice website with just HTML and CSS but PHP is required for login or data sending for MySQL.

HTML > CSS > PHP > MySQL

That is the order I started learning.[/quote]why are you putting sql after php? that’s more like together generally speaking.

Read full topic

item.title: PHP or HTML
item.dc:creator: @xen0n xen0n
item.description:
@xen0n wrote:

Begin with HTML/XHTML to learn the basic structure of a website.

Then move to CSS to get an understanding of how you can style your website.

In reality you can make a really nice website with just HTML and CSS but PHP is required for login or data sending for MySQL.

HTML > CSS > PHP/MySQL

That is the order I started learning.

Read full topic

item.title: PHP or HTML
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“Ecko, post:15, topic:451238”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=554127.msg4060368#msg4060368 date=1343356477]

…?

PHP is a HTML per-processor. It generates HTML.

wat

HTML is markup and is processed by the browser (client). PHP is processed and interpreted by the web server.

He meant pre*-processor. Which makes sense because it is processed before the hypertext (aka PHP: Hypertext Pre-processor).
[/quote]
i still don’t get what he means by it generates html[/quote]

In most cases it generates HTML, like when you’re echoing out data or using output buffering.

Read full topic

item.title: PHP or HTML
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

PHP obviously… but you need Html knowledge to really do anything major with PHP. What I suggest is to go to actual college to learn html, take a web design course as well that will go a long with this. Practice making secure sites for about half a year. Then start your adventure into PHP.

Good luck young grasshopper

Read full topic

item.title: PHP or HTML
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:4, topic:451238”]http://code.google.com/edu/submissions/html-css-javascript/

Gets you started on HTML/CSS/JScript, they say these are the basis for a site, I’d imagine that PHP could replace JS, but I’m not entirely sure.[/quote]

PHP and Javascript are two different things. One runs on the server and the other (mainly) on the client. I don’t think Javascript will necessarily replace PHP.

Read full topic

item.title: PHP or HTML
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

Google Developers

University Consortium  |  Google Developers

The University Consortium is no longer actively maintained.

Gets you started on HTML/CSS/JScript, they say these are the basis for a site, I’d imagine that PHP could replace JS, but I’m not entirely sure.

Read full topic

item.title: PHP or HTML
item.dc:creator: @Dunder_Mifflin1 Dunder Mifflin
item.description:
@Dunder_Mifflin1 wrote:

justaguy:

PHP is obviously more powerful than HTML… But you can’t get away with developing websites without any HTML knowledge. So learn what HTML and PHP are. Begin by probably taking 20 minutes or so to understand what HTML is and memorize some basic tags (that’s all it really takes). Then you can move on to learning PHP.

Thanks

Read full topic
